Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 2

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 211, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 728, 711]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
At a certain shop, customers arrive independently and randomly at a constant average rate of 23.4 per hour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 144, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that, in a randomly chosen 1-minute period, at least 2 customers arrive. [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 917, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 146, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 367, 918, 400]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) denotes the number of customers who arrive in a randomly chosen 1-hour period.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 414, 180, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 414, 918, 432]]<|/det|>
State a suitable approximating distribution for \(X\), giving the value(s) of any parameter(s). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 535, 180, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 535, 678, 554]]<|/det|>
Use your approximating distribution to find \(\mathrm{P}(20 < X < 30)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 535, 918, 554]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 567, 917, 925]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
The lengths of pencils made at a factory are normally distributed. The standard deviation of the lengths is \(\sigma \mathrm{cm}\) , and the mean is supposed to be \(10\mathrm{cm}\). An inspector thinks that the mean is actually greater than \(10\mathrm{cm}\). He takes a random sample of 50 pencils produced at the factory and finds that the mean of these 50 lengths is \(10.03\mathrm{cm}\). He then carries out a hypothesis test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 775, 168]]<|/det|>
He finds that the value of the test statistic \(z\) is 1.995 correct to 3 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 180, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 390, 198]]<|/det|>
Calculate the value of \(\sigma\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 210, 917, 477]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 490, 180, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 490, 658, 508]]<|/det|>
Carry out the hypothesis test at the \(2.5\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 520, 917, 785]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 800, 146, 819]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 800, 920, 819]]<|/det|>
Explain whether it was necessary to use the Central Limit Theorem in carrying out the test. [1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 831, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 96, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 920, 110]]<|/det|>
A machine dispenses coffee into cups. The volume, \(V \text{cm}^3\), of coffee in a cup was measured for a random sample of 150 cups. The results were summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 120, 650, 140]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma \nu = 46 350\qquad \Sigma \nu^2 = 14 410 800\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 154, 146, 173]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 154, 180, 173]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 153, 915, 173]]<|/det|>
Calculate unbiased estimates of the population mean, \(\mu\), and population variance, \(\sigma^2\). [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 183, 917, 389]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 402, 180, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 402, 529, 420]]<|/det|>
Calculate a \(95\%\) confidence interval for \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 402, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 431, 917, 640]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 648, 920, 699]]<|/det|>
<pre>Another random sample of \(n\) cups of coffee is taken, where \(100 < n < 120\). A \(95\%\) confidence interval for \(\mu\) is calculated using this sample. You may assume that, for large samples, unbiased estimates of \(\sigma^2\) are very similar.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 711, 148, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 711, 920, 746]]<|/det|>
Without calculation, state whether this confidence interval would be wider or narrower than the confidence interval found in part (a)(ii). Give a reason for your answer. [2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 757, 917, 932]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Emma needs to choose one person at random from three people, \(P\) , \(Q\) and \(R\) . She plans to throw two fair coins and note the number, \(n\) , of heads. If \(n\) is 0, she will choose \(P\) . If \(n\) is 1, she will choose \(Q\) . If \(n\) is 2, she will choose \(R\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 831, 153]]<|/det|>
By considering probabilities, show that the choice made by this method is not random. [2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 917, 492]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 505, 651, 523]]<|/det|>
Later, Emma has to choose two people at random from three people.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 537, 149, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 537, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
Describe how Emma could use a single throw of a fair six-sided dice to make this random choice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 555, 920, 572]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 585, 917, 910]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 920, 126]]<|/det|>
In Urberia, the masses, in kilograms, of men have the distribution N(70.3, \(5.9^{2}\)). A certain footbridge in Urberia can take a maximum safe load of 1500 kg. When \(n\) men stand on the bridge, the probability that the bridge is unsafe is less than 0.01.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 138, 603, 157]]<|/det|>
Stating a necessary assumption, find the maximum value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 138, 920, 157]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 168, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 72, 605, 90]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(X\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 104, 618, 145]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}ax & 0\leqslant x\leqslant b,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 149, 341, 166]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 146, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 177, 304, 202]]<|/det|>
Show that \(a = \frac{2}{b^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 460, 146, 478]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 459, 390, 478]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{P}(X < \mathrm{E}(X)) = \frac{4}{9}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 459, 920, 478]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
In the past, one quarter of job applicants at a certain firm had first-class degrees. A change is made in the job description and a director of the firm believes that, on average, the proportion of job applicants with first class degrees has decreased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 134, 918, 166]]<|/det|>
In the month following the change, there were 35 job applicants, and \(r\) of these had first-class degrees. The firm carried out a hypothesis test at the \(4\%\) significance level to test the director's belief.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 146, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 180, 918, 212]]<|/det|>
Use a binomial distribution to find the largest value of \(r\) that would provide sufficient evidence that the director's belief is correct.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 197, 918, 215]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
<pre>In another month, the director carries out a similar test at the \(4\%\) significance level using the 35 job applicants from that month.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 148, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 918, 153]]<|/det|>
Explain the meaning of a Type I error in this context, and state the probability of a Type I error. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 170, 915, 396]]<|/det|>
......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 412, 146, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 412, 918, 445]]<|/det|>
Given that the proportion of job applicants with first class degrees this year is actually 0.05, find the probability of a Type II error. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 915, 945]]<|/det|>
......

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 72, 567, 88]]<|/det|>
# Additional page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 101, 917, 135]]<|/det|>
